com.google.appinventor.client.editor.simple.components

Class MockNonVisibleComponent

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.UIObject
      • com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.Widget
        • com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.Composite
          • com.google.appinventor.client.editor.simple.components.MockComponent
            • com.google.appinventor.client.editor.simple.components.MockNonVisibleComponent
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    DragSource, PropertyChangeListener, HasAttachHandlers, HasHandlers, EventListener, HasVisibility, IsRenderable, IsWidget, SourcesMouseEvents

    public final class MockNonVisibleComponent
extends MockComponent
    Class for components without a visual representation, such as sensors.

    To add a new non-visual component:

    1. Put the image for the component's icon in appengine/src/com/google/appinventor/images/FILENAME (substituting the actual filename).
    2. In the class implementing the component (in the directory components/src/com/google/appinventor/components/runtime/), make sure the DesignerComponent annotation includes the following key-value pairs:
      • nonVisible = true
      • iconName = "images/FILENAME"
    3. For good performance in fetching image files:
      • Add a ClientBundle.Source annotation and corresponding method to appengine/src/com/google/appinventor/client/Images.java.
      • Add a mapping from the name of the icon to this new method to the method initBundledImages() in appengine/src/com/google/appinventor/client/editor/simple/palette/SimpleComponentDescriptor.java.
    Author:
    sharon@google.com (Sharon Perl)

      • isVisibleComponent

        public final boolean isVisibleComponent()
        Indicates whether a component has a visible representation.

        The return value of this method will not change upon successive invocations. This is always false for subclasses of this class.

        Specified by:

        public final int getPreferredHeight()

        Callers should be aware that most components cannot calculate their preferred size correctly until they are attached to the UI; see Composite.isAttached(). Unattached components are liable to return 0 for any query about their preferred size.
